In our previous study, the activity and stability of the Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst were enhanced by mixing physically with NiO in methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) reaction. It has been confirmed that the physically mixed NiO not only promoted the dispersion of MoC x active sites but also reduced the coke formation on the MoC x owing to the CNTs growth on Ni. However, the promotional effect of NiO was limited when the particle size was reduced, due to the excessive interaction with MoO x (forming NiMoO4) which is detrimental to the MoC x dispersion. In this study, to overcome the limitation, silica shell on NiO particles with various sizes (5, 15, 110 nm) was introduced. The catalyst with silica shell coated NiO with the size of 15 nm exhibited a significant improvement in both BTX yield and stability, and the catalyst with silica shell coated NiO with the size of 5 nm achieved the highest maximum BTX yield, about 7.2%. This study demonstrates that the catalytic performance improved as the NiO particle size decreased with the introduction of the silica shell. Combined transmission electron microscopy-energy dispersive spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, temperature-programmed surface reaction of methane, CO chemisorption, visible Raman, and thermogravimetric analysis allowed us to confirm that a thin silica shell further enhances the MoC x dispersion while preventing the formation of Ni-Mo complexes. However, when the size of NiO decreased to 5 nm, CNT growth on Ni was limited during the reaction, which is crucial for reducing coke formation on Mo active sites, thereby resulting in the decreased catalyst stabilization ability of Ni. Overall, this study indicates that the introduction of a silica shell in a controlled way can significantly enhance the promotional effect of physically mixed NiO on MDA. Graphical Abstract In the MDA reaction, the physical mixing of silica shell-coated NiO with Mo/ZSM-5 facilitates methane activation on NiO, which in turn promotes the reduction of MoO x to MoC x , leading to enhanced BTX production. Keywords Methane dehydroaromatization Mo/HZSM-5 BTX Physical mixing NiO Silica shell Carbon nanotube 1 Introduction The average temperature on Earth continues to rise annually, accompanied by an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events, thus intensifying global concerns regarding climate change. Methane, the principal component of natural gas and shale gas, is one of the most significant greenhouse gases, alongside carbon dioxide and nitrous oxide. Major sources of methane emissions include the extraction of natural resources, the livestock industry, and notably, petrochemical processes such as steam cracking and naphtha catalytic cracking (NCC) [1–4]. Given its abundance, methane is increasingly recognized as a potential carbon source that could substitute for petroleum in various industrial applications. Rather than using methane solely as a combustion-based energy source, there is growing interest in its conversion into value-added products [5–7]. Methane utilization has been explored through both direct and indirect conversion pathways. Direct conversion includes the one-step transformation of methane into valuable feedstocks such as ethane, ethylene, and aromatics, while indirect conversion does the initial transformation of methane into synthesis gas, followed by further processing to produce the desired final products, for example, the Fischer-Tropsch process [8,9]. However, the high activation energy required to cleave the C-H bond in methane results in the low conversion and large energy input, which pose challenges for the commercialization of these technologies [10]. Among the various methane conversion reactions, including steam reforming, partial oxidation, and methanol synthesis, the methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) reaction particularly stands out as promising because it is a non-oxidative reaction, which allows it to avoid direct CO2 emissions. The MDA reaction directly converts methane into benzene, toluene, and xylene (BTX), which are essential feedstocks for a broad range of petrochemical processes, including the production of styrene, nylon, and synthetic rubber [11–13]. Since Wang et al. first reported the MDA reaction using Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst in 1993, extensive research has been conducted to elucidate the reaction mechanism of MDA over Mo-based HZSM-5 catalysts and advance catalyst development [14]. To activate methane by breaking its C-H bond, the Mo oxides present in the Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst must first undergo a precarburization process, converting them into active Mo oxycarbide or Mo carbide species [15–17]. Once methane is activated, it can be converted into aromatics through a mono-functional or bi-functional mechanism, although the precise pathway remains a topic of debate [18–20]. According to the mono-functional mechanism, MoC x sites are responsible for both methane activation and aromatics formation, forming a hydrocarbon pool that comprises various aromatics and oligomers. Within the hydrocarbon pool, alkyl groups formed by activated methyl radicals are dynamically attached to and detached from polyaromatic compounds, eventually resulting in the formation of BTX with the aid shape selectivity of zeolite [21–23]. Conversely, the bi-functional mechanism proposes that activated methane initially undergoes coupling to form primary C2 intermediates, which then oligomerize at the Brønsted acid sites of the zeolite, ultimately leading to the formation of aromatics [24–26]. A critical challenge of the Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst for MDA is the formation of coke, which can block MoC x active sites and zeolite pore channels, thereby hindering the mass transfer of reactants and leading to the gradual catalyst deactivation [27–29]. Therefore, numerous studies have focused on improving both the BTX yield and stability of the Mo/HZSM-5-based catalysts [30]. These investigations include exploring different types of microporous zeolites, such as MCM-22 (MWW), TNU-9 (TUN), and IM-5 [31–35]. Efforts have also been directed towards managing the external acid sites that contribute to the severe coke formation and modifying the pore structure of the ZSM-5 through techniques such as silylation and post-treatments [36–38]. Furthermore, extensive researches have been conducted on the introduction of multifunctional transition metal promoters such as Fe, Co, Zn, Cu, Ni, Re to facilitate the activation of Mo active sites [39–43]. In our previous research, we successfully improved both the BTX yield and the durability of the Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst by physically mixing it with NiO [44]. Further investigations revealed that the catalytic performance was maximized for the optimum particle size of NiO [45]. When the NiO size was larger than 36 nm, a reduction in size enhanced catalytic activity by promoting MoO x activation at lower temperatures. However, when the NiO size was reduced below a certain threshold (36 nm), the activity decreased instead, because it tended to react with external MoO x to form NiMoO4, causing Mo agglomeration and delayed reduction, which in turn reduced MoC x dispersion [45]. To sum up, despite the general expectation that smaller NiO sizes would enhance the catalytic effect, there was a critical size below which further reduction becomes counterproductive. Therefore, reducing the particle size of NiO without a strong interaction with external MoO x could potentially lower the activation temperature of MoO x , thereby increasing catalytic activity. Hence, in this study, we introduced a silica shell on the NiO particles, physically mixed with Mo/HZSM-5, to maintain the MoO x activation-promoting effect at smaller NiO sizes while preventing unfavorable interactions between NiO and MoO x . The thickness of the silica shell was influenced by the size of the NiO particles. For nano-sized NiO, an optimal shell thickness was achieved that effectively prevented detrimental NiO-MoO x interactions while improving the MoO x activation-promoting effect. This resulted in both enhanced MDA performance and stability. Additionally, we devised a method to further reduce the NiO size by using SiO2 nanosphere as a support for NiO. Although the silica shell in this approach successfully enhanced the promotional effect of NiO, resulting in the highest maximum BTX yield, the excessively small NiO size led to a diminished effect on the stability of MDA. Overall, this study demonstrates that by appropriately introducing silica within the NiO, physically mixed with Mo/HZSM-5, the beneficial effects of NiO can be maximized, providing deeper insights into the size-dependent effects of NiO. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation The core-shell structured NiO@SiO2 samples were prepared by a modified Stöber method [46–48]. Briefly, 0.4 g of bulk NiO or nano NiO (Sigma-Aldrich) was added to ethanol solution of 200 mL. After the solution was stirred for 12 h, NH3·H2O (28 wt%) of 15 mL was added, and then the suspension was sonicated for 30 min. Subsequently, tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, ⩾99%, Aldrich) of 0.3 mL was injected into the suspension. One hour later, the product was collected by centrifugation, washed twice with distilled water and ethanol, and dried at 80 °C in air for 10 h. Dried samples was calcined at 500 °C for 4 h. The silica shell coated bulk NiO and nano NiO are denoted as bulk NiO@SiO2 and nano NiO@SiO2, respectively. Subsequently, we attempted to introduce a silica shell to NiO particles smaller than 10 nm. However, it was challenging to achieve equivalent encapsulation on the NiO surface, because the silica tended to nucleate independently, forming separate silica particles, instead of forming a uniform silica shell. This made it difficult to control the process effectively. To achieve a homogeneous silica shell coating on the extremely small NiO particles (~5 nm), relatively bulky SiO2 nanospheres were first synthesized, and then the NiO was deposited onto these nanospheres. Briefly, SiO2 nanosphere was synthesized by adding H2O of 5.2 mL, NH3·H2O (28 wt%) of 15 mL and TEOS of 7.6 mL to ethanol of 180 mL. After stirring for 6 h, the product was collected by centrifugation, washed with ethanol. Collected sample was dried at 80 °C in air for overnight. The metal contents and Ni/Mo molar ratios of Mo/HZSM-5 physically mixed with silica shell coated NiO were determined using ICP-AES, as shown in Table S1. 2.2 Catalytic activity measurement A fixed-bed quartz reactor with a diameter of 2 cm and a length of 50 cm was used to conduct the MDA reaction over 0.2 g of the catalyst. Crushed catalysts were sieved using a 20–40 mesh screen. As a pretreatment step, catalysts were first activated in the reactor. The reactor was continually heated to 700 °C at a ramping rate of 10 °C/min after being brought to 400 °C with a ramping rate of 20 °C/min. The temperature was then stabilized for 10 min. Weight loss of the post-reaction sample corresponding to the elimination of coke was calculated with weight after water desorption. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Analysis of silica shell coated NiO Figs. 1(a) and (b) present TEM images of synthesized bulk NiO@SiO2 and nano NiO@SiO2, which are silica shell coated NiO particles. It is evident that the NiO particles are uniformly coated with a silica shell of consistent thickness, forming a core-shell structure. The mean sizes of the NiO particles and silica shells were calculated from the TEM images. The mean particle size of bulk NiO@SiO2 synthesized using a relatively bulky NiO precursor, is approximately 110 nm, while the mean particle size of nano NiO@SiO2 is about 15 nm. The mean silica shell thicknesses of two samples are 32 and 4 nm, respectively. These indicate that the thickness of the silica shell increases as the size of the core NiO particle increases, consistent with the phenomenon reported by Li et al. [48]. To reduce the NiO particle size and achieve better dispersion, we impregnated NiO on SiO2 nanospheres and subsequently, a silica shell was introduced through a modified Stöber method. Figs. 1(c) and (g) present the TEM images of NiO/SiO2 and (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2, respectively. Fig. 1(c) confirms that NiO is well supported on the SiO2 nanosphere surfaces before silica shell introduction. The amine functional groups on the exterior of the SiO2 nanospheres assist in strongly anchoring the NiO to the surface. Such SMSI reduces NiO mobility and resulting in relatively small and uniformly dispersed NiO particles [49]. The average size of the NiO nanoparticles in (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2 sample is approximately 5 nm, which is smaller than the previously synthesized silica shell-coated NiO particles. Although the boundary between the core and the shell, both composed of SiO2, is difficult to distinguish in the TEM image (Fig. 1(g)), comparing the particles before and after silica shell introduction allows us to estimate the shell thickness. Upon close inspection (Fig. 1(h)), it can be observed that the NiO particle, initially exposed on the surface of core SiO2 nanospheres, become encapsulated by a newly formed silica layer after the introduction of the silica shell. This silica layer covering the surface of the NiO particles is identified as the silica shell, with a thickness of approximately 4.1 nm. This encapsulation is also indicated by the increase in the average radius of the silica particles, from 48.4 to 52.6 nm, reflecting the successful coating of a 4.2 nm thick silica shell onto the core SiO2 nanospheres. This thickness resembles that of silica shell in nano NiO@SiO2. Consequently, NiO particles with various sizes were successfully coated with a silica shell. Particularly, the silica shell was introduced successfully to the smaller size of NiO particles (~5 nm), maintaining the consistent thickness (4 nm) by supporting NiO on the SiO2 nanospheres followed by the introduction of silica shell. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of the silica shell coated NiO physically mixed with the fresh Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts. The XRD profiles of all samples are consistent with those of their HZSM-5 supports. A peak at 2θ of 27.4°, corresponding to the orthorhombic MoO3 phase, and another at 2θ of 25.7°, corresponding to the MoO2 phase, were observed in all samples [51,52]. This indicates that, despite calcination, the molybdenum oxide in the fresh Mo/HZSM-5 did not achieve complete dispersion on the zeolite surface, likely due to the relatively high Mo loading of approximately 12 wt%. The pronounced peaks in the bulk NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst indicate the presence of larger NiO particles, while the smaller peaks in the nano NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst suggest better dispersion and smaller particle size. Notably, these peaks were almost absent in the (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst, implying that the silica shell coated NiO particles maintain their initial size and the silica shell effectively prevents significant agglomeration of NiO particles during calcination after silica shell coating. As shown in Fig. S1, the physical mixing of NiO particles reduces the total amount of acid sites, particularly strong acid sites. This is likely because nano NiO@SiO₂ or (NiO/SiO₂)@SiO₂ particles are positioned on the surface of the zeolite during the physically mixing process, blocking the external acid sites or pore channel entrances of the zeolite, thereby hindering NH₃ adsorption. Furthermore, as demonstrated in the pyridine adsorption FT-IR spectra (Fig. S2) and summarized in Table 1 , the quantitative analysis of Brønsted acid sites (B) and Lewis acid sites (L) shows a slight decrease when NiO particles are physically mixed. This implies that the Brønsted acid site concentration among catalysts during the reaction does not differ significantly. 3.2 Methane dehydroaromatization results Fig. 3 presents the BTX yield with time-on-stream (TOS) during the MDA reaction over Mo/HZSM-5 physically mixed with various types of silica shell-coated NiO. The catalysts physically mixed with any form of NiO exhibited a higher maximum BTX yield compared to the Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst alone. For the bulk NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst, the introduction of a silica shell resulted in a maximum BTX yield of 5.52%, which is nearly identical to that of the bulk NiO-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst (5.62%), indicating that the silica shell hardly affects the reactivity for the bulk NiO. While the Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst physically mixed with nano-sized NiO (nano NiO-Mo/HZSM-5) achieved a maximum BTX yield of 4.64%, nearly identical with that of Mo/HZSM-5 alone (4.66%), consistent with our previous findings [45], the nano NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst exhibited a significantly higher BTX yield of 5.97%. This value notably exceeds the yields obtained with both the bulk NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 and nano NiO-Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts. The substantial improvement in maximum BTX yield observed for the nano NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst underscores the enhanced catalytic performance achieved by incorporating a silica shell onto the nano-sized NiO. Meanwhile, the (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst, which featured the smallest average NiO particle size, achieved the highest maximum BTX yield of 7.20%. Considering that the NiO/SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst showed even lower performance (5.39%) than the bulk NiO-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst (5.62%), it is evident that the promotional effect of nano-sized NiO supported on the SiO2 nanosphere was also improved by the introduction of silica shell. The deactivation trends of the catalysts varied depending on the presence of the SiO2 nanospheres. The deactivation rate of each catalyst was quantified by dividing the decrease in BTX yield, measured from the point of maximum activity to the end of the reaction, by the corresponding reaction time, as shown in Table S2. First, Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts physically mixed with bulk NiO, bulk NiO@SiO2, nano NiO, and nano NiO@SiO2 exhibited the slower deactivation rate compared to the Mo/HZSM-5, indicating that the physically mixed NiO with Mo/HZSM-5 contributes to enhanced catalytic stability, regardless of the silica shell coating on NiO particles. Particularly, the nano NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst showed a significant improvement in both BTX yield and stability. This catalyst stabilization is primarily explained by the fact that the physically mixed Ni uses coke precursors for CNT formation, thereby inhibiting the accumulation of amorphous coke that could block MoC x active sites and pore channels [44]. However, catalysts with small NiO particles (~5 nm), such as NiO/SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 and (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5, exhibited relatively rapid deactivation rates. Notably, the (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst showed high deactivation rate which is almost identical to that of Mo/HZSM-5. These results suggest that when the NiO particles are dispersed on the SiO2 nanospheres with extremely small sizes, the ability of Ni to accumulate coke decreases, leading to the reduced stabilization ability of Ni. Additionally, this ability to accumulate coke of Ni is further minimized when an additional silica shell is introduced [49]. The deactivation trends will be investigated more extensively in section 3.4 through the physicochemical characterization of the post-reaction catalysts. As shown in Fig. 4 , most of the products are aromatic compounds, with benzene dominating among the BTX products. The selectivity for light alkanes, which are byproducts, remains low, at under 10%. The difference between carbon input and output is attributed to carbon associated with coke formation. At 20 min, BTX selectivity is low, and unmeasured carbon, indicative of coke, is high across all samples. This can be attributed to the induction period, during which MoC x active sites and the hydrocarbon pool are established, resulting in high carbon consumption for carbide and hydrocarbon pool formation [22]. For the Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst (Fig. 4(a)), benzene selectivity initially increases and then declines, while coke formation first decreases and subsequently rises as the reaction progresses. This behavior is attributed to the increasing formation of polyaromatic compounds on acid sites, which are well known precursors for hard coke [54]. However, when NiO is physically mixed, as shown in Figs. 4(b) and (c), the benzene selectivity continues to increase due to the promoting effect of Ni, which enhances the dispersion of MoC x within the zeolite channels and prevents the pore blockage by coke formation, as will be discussed later. Furthermore, the formation of CNTs on Ni suppresses and delays the formation of polyaromatic coke, resulting in a consistent reduction in coke formation and, consequently, enhanced catalytic stability. On the other hand, Fig. 4(d) shows that the (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst exhibits an exceptional trend similar to Mo/HZSM-5, indicating a comparable rate of deactivation. This is because, in the case of the (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst with very small NiO particles, Ni cannot fully function as a CNT seed, leading to coke formation behavior that differs from other catalysts physically mixed with NiO, as also will be discussed later [49]. 3.3 The effects of silica shell coated NiO on the MoCx dispersion Numerous studies have established that a process known as precarburization is required for Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts to exhibit methane activation activity in the MDA reaction, where Mo oxides are reduced to Mo carbide species [55,56]. During this process, the Mo oxides supported on HZSM-5 are reduced by methane to form Mo oxycarbide or Mo carbide species, which become mobile and redisperse within the internal and external pores of the HZSM-5 structure [57,58]. The resulting MoC x active species can exist within the micropores as clusters or become strongly anchored to the T sites of the zeolite, which is critical for achieving high BTX selectivity [59,60]. For optimal performance, these Mo carbide active sites should be well dispersed within the pores of the zeolite, as its high dispersion gives rise to enhanced BTX selectivity as well as the delayed sintering of MoC x particles [29,61]. Therefore, the dispersion of Mo carbide plays a crucial role in determining the catalytic activity. Fig. 5 presents the CH4-TPSR results during the precarburization process of the catalysts. In these profiles, the consumption of methane, coupled with the production of CO and hydrogen, indicates the reduction of elements (MoO x and NiO) in catalysts. For the Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst physically mixed with NiO, both Mo oxides and NiO are reduced to form MoC x and metallic Ni, respectively, during the pretreatment. The sequence of these reduction events can be clarified through CH4-TPSR analysis. According to the CH4-TPSR results over Mo/HZSM-5 and bulk NiO-Mo/HZSM-5 in the previous study, the initial evolution peaks of H₂ and CO are associated with CH₄ decomposition during the reduction of NiO to metallic Ni, while peaks at higher temperatures correspond to the reduction of MoO x to MoC x [44,45]. The promoting effect of NiO physical mixing on MDA has been reported that metallic Ni facilitates the reduction of MoO x , lowering the activation temperature at which the reduction of MoO x to MoC x occurs. Thereby, the addition of NiO promotes anchoring of MoC x on framework Al and prevents agglomeration of MoC x active sites. This results in an enhanced dispersion of MoC x into the zeolite channels, which enhances benzene production [44]. We conducted similar investigations for Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts physically mixed with silica shell-coated NiO. For the bulk NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 (Fig. 5(a)), the reduction of NiO occurred first at 552 °C, followed by methane consumption and MoO x activation at 652 °C. In the case of the nano NiO@ SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst (Fig. 5(b)), the reduction of NiO began at 491 °C, accompanied by the sustained methane consumption and hydrogen production, followed by the secondary peak of CO evolution at 609 °C where MoO x is activated to MoC x . Notably, for the nano NiO@SiO2 (~15 nm), the reduction temperature of NiO is significantly lower by more than 50 °C compared to bulk NiO@SiO2. At the onset of NiO reduction in the nano NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst, the sharp and simultaneous increase in CO and hydrogen evolution contrasts with the gradual increase observed in the bulk NiO@SiO2-Mo/ HZSM-5 catalyst. These results suggest that the rapid reduction of NiO occurred over the nano NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst, while NiO is gradually reduced to metallic Ni for the bulk NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst, indicating that smaller NiO particles can be reduced more readily by methane. Additionally, the following increase in production of hydrogen and continuous methane consumption right after the NiO reduction in the nano NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst indicate simultaneously following the formation of active carbon species on the Ni particle surfaces. For the case of (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst (Fig. 5(c)), NiO reduction occurred at a much lower temperature of 442 °C, with MoO x activation at 589 °C, the lowest temperature observed among the catalysts. To sum up, the smaller the initial size of NiO particles, the higher its reactivity with methane, facilitating its reduction to Ni particles at lower temperature and the formation of active carbon species. When silica shell was introduced to each NiO particles, the NiO reduction temperature was slightly lowered to 551 °C for bulk NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 from 576 °C for bulk NiO-Mo/HZSM-5 and to 491 °C for nano NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 and 442 °C (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 [44]. These temperatures are similar to the reduction temperatures of nano-sized NiO at the range of 4 to 36 nm (403 to 466 °C) [45]. This can be explained that the silica shell effectively prevents the formation of NiMoO4 which causes an increase in the reduction temperature of NiO particles [45]. The order of the MoO x activation temperature was bulk NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 (652 °C) > nano NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 (609 °C) > (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 (589 °C), which directly correlated with the order of the maximum BTX yield. This relationship suggests that the Mo activation temperature decreases with decreasing Ni particle size introduced with the silica shell, and that the lower activation temperature is attributed to the higher maximum BTX yield. This can be explained by the fact that the reduction of MoO x to MoC x at a lower temperature inhibits migration of MoO x due to its low Tammann temperature (534 K), which can prevent agglomeration of MoO x and MoC x , thereby enhancing MoC x dispersion and catalytic performance [62]. Notably, when silica shell coating was introduced, the activation temperature decreased proportionally with the NiO particle size, compared to the result that the MoO x activation temperature increased to 658 °C when the NiO particle size was reduced to 4 nm in our previous study [45]. This implies the beneficial effect of the silica shell. When bare nano NiO particles were physically mixed, the formation of Ni-Mo complexes owing to the strong Ni-Mo reaction hindered MoO x activation and raised its temperature during the pretreatment process. However, by introducing a silica shell, the protective effect prevents the strong interaction between Ni and Mo, which suppresses MoO x reduction, while produced active carbon species on the Ni nanoparticles, thereby enhancing the Ni-promoted activation of MoO x and MoC x dispersion. It can be summarized that our findings imply that methane reduces NiO to metallic Ni during the pretreatment stage, and that metallic Ni facilitates the conversion of MoO x into MoC x at lower temperatures with higher dispersion. To strengthen this point, the MoC x dispersions of pretreated catalysts were compared based on CO chemisorption, as shown in Table 2 . Compared to pretreatment samples, post-reaction samples (Table S3) showed the decreased CO adsorption, suggesting that the agglomeration of MoC x at high temperatures during the reaction, leads to a reduction in MoC x dispersion and the CO adsorption on coke is negligible [44]. Thus, coke generated after the reaction had minimal impact on CO adsorption, confirming that the CO uptake observed in post-reaction samples is attributable to MoC x . The CO uptake of pretreated Mo/HZSM-5 increased from 0.19 to 0.62, 0.83, and 0.91 cm3/g when physically mixed with bulk NiO@SiO2, nano NiO@SiO2, and (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2, respectively. For the case of post-reaction catalysts, CO uptake increased from 0.08 to 0.54, 0.60, and 0.61 cm3/g after the addition of bulk NiO@SiO2, nano NiO@SiO2, and (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2, respectively (Table S3). These results confirm that catalysts with lower activation temperatures had higher CO uptake, providing the compelling evidence of increased MoC x dispersion. Figs. 6(a) –(c) shows the TEM images and corresponding particle size distribution diagrams for pretreated catalysts. Prior to the particle size measurement, Ni and MoC x particles were distinguished in the TEM images. For the bulk NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 and nano NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts, the Ni particles were relatively large and existed independently, making it easier to differentiate them from the HZSM-5 and MoC x particles. Notably, for the nano NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst, CNTs were already formed during the pretreatment process, as shown in Fig. 6(b). In contrast, for the (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst (Fig. 6(c)), the smaller size of the Ni particles made it challenging to distinguish them. To address this, additional EDS mapping analysis for the TEM image of (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst was performed, as shown in Fig. S4. During the pretreatment process, Ni, initially supported on silica nanospheres and coated with a silica shell, largely remained fixed on the silica nanospheres. In contrast, MoC x underwent redispersion, with some MoC x particles relocating from HZSM-5 to silica nanospheres, resulting in the coexistence of Ni and MoC x on the silica nanospheres. To ensure accurate calculation of the mean particle size of MoC x , calculation was conducted specifically for MoC x dispersed on HZSM-5. The bulk NiO@SiO₂-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst exhibited the largest mean particle size of 7.9 nm, while the nano NiO@SiO₂-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst showed a smaller mean particle size of 5.5 nm. The (NiO/SiO₂)@SiO₂-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst demonstrated the smallest mean particle size of 4.4 nm among the catalysts. These observations align with the trends of activity trends (Fig. 3) and MoC x dispersion identified from MoO x activation temperature analysis (Fig. 5), and CO chemisorption analysis (Table 2). Combining with the earlier CH4-TPSR results, it can be inferred that catalysts with lower MoO x activation temperatures had higher MoC x dispersion with smaller mean particle size and better catalytic activity. Comparing bulk NiO-Mo/HZSM-5 from our previous study and bulk NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5, the introduction of a silica shell actually raised the MoO x activation temperature from 633 to 652 °C and reduced the CO uptake, indicating the decreased MoC x dispersion, which correspondingly led to the reduced activity (Fig. 3) [44]. This can be explained by the fact that the thick silica shell reduces the interaction between Ni and MoO x , thereby diminishing the beneficial effect of Ni on MoC x dispersion. 3.4 The effects of silica shell coated NiO on the coke formation after MDA reaction MDA reaction using Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts inevitably face significant deactivation arising from the coke formation. This is mainly attributed to the accumulation of polyaromatic carbonaceous coke species at the Mo active sites or within the Brønsted acid sites of the zeolite, which blocks the Mo active sites and zeolite pore channels, resulting in a rapid loss of catalytic activity. To mitigate the deactivation, it is crucial to reduce coke formation, particularly the accumulation of polyaromatic carbonaceous coke inside and outside the zeolite, which impedes mass transfer of the reactants. Ni could be an effective coke consumer, as it is well known for its ability to promote the formation of whisker-like carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and has been extensively studied for CNT production. Baker et al. [63] demonstrated that the presence of Ni particles can catalytically promote the growth of carbon filaments, consuming carbon and preventing the catalyst from being deactivated by amorphous coke deposition. Similarly, Gohier et al. [64] found that certain metal particles, including Ni, encouraged the creation of CNTs, which could lessen the amount of coke deposition that deactivated the catalyst, resulting in enhancing its overall stability and lifetime. We achieved the selective formation of coke species by introducing NiO as a promoter and reported that the Ni particles present on the external surface of the zeolite utilize coke precursors for the growth of CNTs. This prevents the blockage of Mo active sites, slowing down the catalyst deactivation process when Mo/HZSM-5 is physically mixed with NiO in our previous studies [44,45]. Consequently, physically mixing NiO with Mo/HZSM-5 allows us to control the coke formation that does not deactivate the Mo active sites, thereby increasing the catalyst stability in MDA reaction. We conducted coke analysis on the post-reaction catalysts aiming to verify if NiO coated with a silica shell would exhibit similar effects, particularly concerning coke formation. XRD patterns for pretreated and post-reaction catalysts are shown in Figs. 7(a) and (b) , respectively. There were no peaks arising from Mo-related phases for the pretreated catalysts, implying that the Mo oxide clusters on the external surface were well carburized and dispersed during the pretreatment process. For pretreated bulk NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 and nano NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5, peaks corresponding to the metallic Ni phases at 2θ of 44.5° and 2θ of 51.9° were observed, while the intensity of NiO peaks decreased, indicating that NiO particles were reduced to metallic Ni particles during the pretreatment process, even when coated with a silica shell. The particle size of Ni in nano NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 remained smaller than that in bulk NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 during the pretreatment, suggesting that the reduction of NiO to metallic Ni is not significantly hindered by the silica shell and significant agglomeration is avoided during the pretreatment process. Additionally, the formation of CNTs was confirmed by the typical peaks for CNTs at 2θ of 26.22°, corresponding to the (002) plane of graphite-2H in these two catalysts. For the case of (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst, the NiO peaks that were nearly absent in the fresh state remained nearly absent in the pretreated sample, and there was no peaks arising from metallic Ni peaks. This indicates that the strong interaction between NiO and the SiO2 nanospheres prevented Ni from agglomerating during the reduction process, thus maintaining a well-dispersed state. Furthermore, there was little peak arising from the CNT phase in this catalyst. In the case of XRD patterns for the post-reaction catalysts (Fig. 7(b)), the presence of peaks arising from metallic Ni indicates that the metallic Ni initially formed during the pretreatment step was sustained throughout the reaction process. Additionally, the negligible change in the peak intensity of metallic Ni at 2θ = 44.5° observed between the pretreated and post-reaction catalysts indicates that the particle size of Ni did not change significantly during the reaction, and no substantial Ni agglomeration occurred. Notably, for the bulk NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 and nano NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts, the intensity of the CNTs peaks significantly increased after the reaction. In contrast, the (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst showed almost no increase in the intensity of these peaks. This suggests that while core-shell structured silica-coated NiO particles can act as seeds for CNT formation, the well dispersed NiO supported on SiO2 nanospheres, subsequently coated with a silica shell do not effectively serve as seeds for CNT growth. This can be attributed to the extremely small particle sizes of Ni (~5 nm), which has less Ni terraces, facilitating CNT growth, compared to bulk or nano NiO@SiO2 particles [49]. Gohier et al. [64] also reported that extremely small Ni particle sizes of less than 5 nm typically result in the formation of very thin single-walled CNTs, leading to the minimal CNT formation with very low density especially on Ni seeds. It can be inferred that the carbon sources were likely used for the formation of other types of coke rather than contributing to the CNT formation on Ni particles. Additionally, no peaks corresponding to any crystalline Ni and Mo complexes or alloy forms were observed in both the pretreated and post-reaction catalysts. Fig. 7(c) shows the visible Raman spectroscopy spectra of the post-reaction catalysts. For the CNT reference, characteristic peaks are observed at 1348, 1578, 1607, and 2689 cm–1. The peaks at 1348 and 1578 cm–1 correspond to the disorder-induced planes of graphite and the ordered in-plane sp 2 hybridized carbon bond stretching vibration of graphite, respectively, referred to the D1-band and G-band, respectively [65–67]. The D1-band indicates in-plane breathing vibrations of sp 2-bonded carbon within structural defects, especially observed in disordered graphitic carbon species and edges of the graphitic crystallites [68,69]. The small D2-band, located at a slightly higher wavenumber of 1607 cm–1 than the G-band, corresponds to the edges of very small or disordered graphitic crystallites [68,70]. Additionally, 2D-peak at 2689 cm–1, which is characteristically observed in CNTs, is an overtone of the D1-band and is closely related to the two-dimensionality of graphene [71]. For the post-reaction Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst, a broadly increased D1-band and a slightly right-shifted G-band were observed, with no 2D-peak. These D1-band and shifted G-band peaks correspond to sp 3 rich polymeric amorphous carbon, known to be coke generated on MoC x that accelerates deactivation [28]. The slight shift to the right of G-band is explained by the increase in the D2-band peak with the amount of disordered carbon species. However, when NiO@SiO2 was physically mixed with the Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst, the overall intensity of the carbon peaks, including the D1-band and G-band, decreased, and the G-band shifted asymmetrically to the left caused by the notable decrease in the D2-band after the MDA reaction. Notably, a 2D-peak appeared around 2689 cm–1. These changes indicate the reduced formation of amorphous polyaromatic coke with the increased amount of ordered graphitic carbon, originating from CNTs. This suggests that coke precursors generated on the MoC x active sites migrated to the Ni particles, forming CNTs instead of amorphous coke on Mo active sites. These findings are consistent with the graphite-2H peak observed in the XRD patterns (Fig. 7(b)). On the other hand, the (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst showed distinct D1-band at 1348 cm–1 and G-band at 1600 cm–1, but no 2D-peak, similar to the post-reaction Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst. The G-band shifted to the right because of the notable increase in the D2-band, indicating that most of the coke formed as polymeric amorphous carbon on the MoC x sites instead of CNT growth. TGA analysis and DTG results for the post-reaction catalysts are shown in Figs. 8(a) and (b) . For the case of Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst, coke is predominantly removed at 568 °C. However, when NiO is physically mixed with the catalyst, the coke combustion peak is divided into two distinct peaks, occurring around 485 and 617 °C. Based on prior observations, this behavior can be attributed to the role of Ni in capturing polyaromatic hard coke precursors that can accumulate on the zeolite surface, subsequently leading to the formation of CNTs. The coke combustion peak shifted to the lower temperature, likely corresponds to the formation of relatively soft and amorphous coke species deposited on the Mo active sites, while the high-temperature peak is associated with the combustion of various sizes of CNTs that have formed on the Ni particles [72–74]. In contrast, the (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst exhibits significantly suppressed CNT formation, as evidenced by the minimal presence of a CNT combustion peak above 600 °C. Instead, this catalyst primarily displays a low-temperature peak at 494 °C and a mid-temperature peak at 560 °C, corresponding to the combustion of amorphous soft coke and polyaromatic hard coke, respectively. As shown in Fig. 8(c), the quantitative analysis of coke species offers insights into how the introduction of each type of silica shell coated NiO affects the formation of different coke species. For the Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst, the coke species consist entirely of polyaromatic hard coke, which accumulates on the Mo active sites and zeolite surface, leading to a significant pore blockage and catalyst deactivation [75,76]. In contrast, catalysts physically mixed with bulk NiO, bulk NiO@SiO₂, and nano NiO@SiO₂, which exhibited enhanced stability in the MDA reaction, the low-temperature soft coke (decomposing below 500 °C) and a large amount of CNTs on Ni particles were observed. Simultaneously, the proportion of hard coke, which critically causes activity loss, was significantly reduced. This observation is attributed to the role of Ni particles in capturing polyaromatic hard coke precursors from the MoC x active sites. However, unlike other silica shell coated NiO physical mixtures, the (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst produced almost no CNTs, resulting in a relatively higher proportion of hard coke. This behavior can be explained by the extremely small Ni particles, which are ineffective in promoting CNT growth, thereby limiting their capacity to sufficiently consume polyaromatic hard coke precursors from the Mo active sites. Fig. 9 shows the TEM images of the post-reaction catalysts. For both bulk NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 and nano NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 (Figs. 9 (a) and (b)), the silica shell was no longer visible in the post-reaction samples, and some of Ni particles acted as seeds for the growth of filamentous CNTs. These observations indicate that the silica shell around the NiO particles was primarily destroyed or removed during the reaction process. Wang et al. [77] reported that in DRM reactions using Ni coated with a silica shell in core-shell catalysts, the reactants methane and CO2 could permeate the silica shell, reaching the Ni particles inside, where coke formation first occurred. In other words, coke formation on the surface of Ni particles initiates in the presence of a spatial gap between the silica shell and Ni particles with the penetration of methane. Thus, the destruction of silica shell in NiO@SiO2 occurred due to the formation of coke at the interface between the Ni particles and the silica shell, which allowed CNTs to grow. Additionally, the mean thickness of CNTs which is similar to the diameter of Ni particle is about 0.15 µm for the post-reaction bulk NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 and about 0.03 µm for the post-reaction nano NiO@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5. The slight increase in the size of Ni particles from their initial sizes is attributed to the accumulation of coke on the Ni particle surfaces, which added to the particle size. This likely led to the further coke formation, resulting in the destruction of the silica shell and the growth of CNTs. For the case of (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst Ni particle sizes remained small about a few nanometers after the reaction, as shown in Fig. 9(c), indicating that the reduced Ni particles are well fixed on the SiO2 nanospheres during the pretreatment process. This indicates that the SMSI between Ni and SiO2 nanospheres and the silica shell coating also effectively decrease Ni mobility, preventing Ni agglomeration which results in the significant coke formation on Ni particles during the reaction [78]. Indeed, CNT growth was less pronounced on the catalysts with (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2, unlike the Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts physically mixed with bulk NiO or core-shell structured silica-coated NiO. It has been reported that the catalytic growth of filamentous CNTs also relies heavily on carbon solubility and diffusion, so any blockage on the Ni surface or reduction in carbon diffusion rate can inhibit filamentous carbon growth [63]. Considering the minimal CNT growth on Ni particles, the exposure of Ni is significantly reduced when NiO is supported on SiO2 nanospheres and coated with a silica shell. It can be explained that the Ni particles are tightly bound to the SiO2 nanosphere surface with minimal voids between the silica surfaces and Ni particles due to the SMSI, suppressing the accumulation of active carbon species on the Ni particle surfaces which lead to the CNTs growth. Consequently, coke formation and CNT growth on Ni particle surfaces are minimized due to the SMSI between Ni and silica, leading to the coke precursors accumulating on MoC x active sites [49]. This was evidenced by the large D and G band peaks in Raman spectra and the Mo-associated coke peak at 550 °C in DTG. As a result, the stabilization ability of Ni significantly diminished in the (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst, resulting in the rapid deactivation rate, although it had the highest maximum BTX yield. 4 Conclusions In this study, we systematically investigated the effects of silica shell-coated NiO on the catalytic performance of Mo/HZSM-5 in MDA. The thickness of the silica shell was found to be proportional to the size of the NiO particles, with the smallest NiO nanoparticles achieved by first supporting NiO on SiO2 nanospheres, followed by silica coating. The presence of the silica shell significantly influenced the catalytic activity, with smaller initial NiO particle sizes leading to higher maximum activity. The thicker silica shell of bulk NiO@SiO2 hindered the promotional effect of Ni, delaying the activation of Mo oxides and consequently reducing catalytic activity compared to catalysts without silica shell. Conversely, the thinner silica shell of nano NiO@SiO2 effectively protect NiO from the significant formation of Ni-Mo complexes and increasing the dispersion of MoC x during the pretreatment, which further enhanced the catalytic activity. Although the core-shell structured silica shell mostly disappeared during the pretreatment process, the stability improvement effect due to CNT formation on Ni particles was also maintained. The (NiO/SiO2)@SiO2-Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst exhibited the lowest Mo oxide activation temperature and the highest MoC x dispersion with the smallest mean particle size of MoC x , resulting in the highest maximum BTX yield among the catalysts. However, the extremely small size of dispersed NiO and the SMSI with SiO2 nanospheres and shells suppressed CNTs growth on the Ni surface, reducing the beneficial effect of coke reduction on Mo active sites, thereby limiting its contribution to stability. In conclusion, this study exhibited that the catalytic performance of Mo/HZSM-5 physically mixed with NiO in MDA reaction could be significantly enhanced by introducing an appropriately designed silica shell on NiO. The introduction of NiO lowers the reduction temperature of MoO x , thereby enhancing the dispersion of MoC x and mitigating the aggregation of MoC x during the reaction. Meanwhile, the introduction of a silica shell plays a supplementary role by protecting nano-sized Ni from strong interactions with Mo that could suppress MoC x dispersion. Additionally, this study using silica shells has provided a deeper understanding about the impact of NiO size in NiO-Mo/HZSM-5 system on MDA reaction. coredata.dc:description: In our previous study, the activity and stability of the Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst were enhanced by mixing physically with NiO in methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) reaction. It has been confirmed that the physically mixed NiO not only promoted the dispersion of MoC x active sites but also reduced the coke formation on the MoC x owing to the CNTs growth on Ni. However, the promotional effect of NiO was limited when the particle size was reduced, due to the excessive interaction with MoO x (forming NiMoO4) which is detrimental to the MoC x dispersion. In this study, to overcome the limitation, silica shell on NiO particles with various sizes (5, 15, 110 nm) was introduced. The catalyst with silica shell coated NiO with the size of 15 nm exhibited a significant improvement in both BTX yield and stability, and the catalyst with silica shell coated NiO with the size of 5 nm achieved the highest maximum BTX yield, about 7.2%. This study demonstrates that the catalytic performance improved as the NiO particle size decreased with the introduction of the silica shell. Combined transmission electron microscopy-energy dispersive spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, temperature-programmed surface reaction of methane, CO chemisorption, visible Raman, and thermogravimetric analysis allowed us to confirm that a thin silica shell further enhances the MoC x dispersion while preventing the formation of Ni-Mo complexes. However, when the size of NiO decreased to 5 nm, CNT growth on Ni was limited during the reaction, which is crucial for reducing coke formation on Mo active sites, thereby resulting in the decreased catalyst stabilization ability of Ni. Overall, this study indicates that the introduction of a silica shell in a controlled way can significantly enhance the promotional effect of physically mixed NiO on MDA.
